participants.participant: Theodore M. Helms, Interim Executive Manager of Investor Relations
Almir Guilherme Barbassa, Chief Financial Officer and Investor Relations Director

plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by and welcome to the Petrobras conference call to discuss the second quarter 2008 results. At this time, all lines are in a listen-only mode. Later there will be a question-and-answer session and instructions will be given at that time. . As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.

Today with us we have Mr. Almir Guilherme Barbassa, CFO and IR Officer and his staff. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Theodore Helms, Investor Relations Executive Manager of Petrobras, who has some additional comments. Please go ahead Mr. Helms.

Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our conference call to discuss second quarter 2008 results. We have a simultaneous webcast on the Internet that can be accessed at the site, www.petrobras.com.br/ir/english.

Before proceeding, I'd like to draw your attention to the slide two. We my make forward-looking statements, which are identified by the use of the words, will, expect and similar that are based on the belief and assumptions of Petrobras's management and on information currently available to the company.

Finally, let me mention that this conference call will discuss Petrobras's results prepared in accordance with Brazilian GAAP. At this moment, we are unable to discuss any issues related to U.S. GAAP results.

The conference call will be conducted by our CFO and Investor Relations Officer, Mr. Almir Guilherme Barbassa. He will comment on the company's operating and financial highlights and the main events during this quarter, and he will be available to answer any questions you may have.
Mr. Barbassa, you may begin.
Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen. It is a pleasure to be here with you and have this opportunity to talk about the second quarter results.

Let me begin by quickly highlighting our record income for the period. Net income totaled R$8.8 billion for the second quarter, an increase of 20% from the prior period. EBITDA increased by 31% from the first quarter of 2008 to reach R$18.1 billion. Higher price, increasing production and cost discipline all contributed to the record earnings.

The cash flow generated continues to be the foundation for integrated books in accordance with our long-term business plan. We are reviewing the plan, which we expect to complete in October. At that time, we'll share with you our expectations for the future.

Let's now go to slide three to look at the national oil and natural gas production. Oil production in Brazil grew by 2% mainly from the continuing hand back of P-52 and P-54. And the completion of new wells in the Alba corridor . Production from the new systems and wells more than offset natural decline from a . For the reminder of the year, P-52 and P-54 will continue to provide most of the production goals, as they achieved their peak capacity of 108,000 barrels per day.

For the rest of the year we have clean water platform coming onstream P-51 and P-53 and FPSO Cidade de Vitória, adding a new total of new capacity production of 460,000 barrels of oil per day. Natural gas contributed substantially to the production growth, increasing 6% during the quarter. This additional production was mainly in non-associated gas from the Manati fields in the Espirito Santa Basin, and associated gas from the new production system in Campos Basin.
It is worth mentioning that later this year we expect to begin producing from Lagosta, Canapu and

Camarupim fields, adding some additional 10 million cubic meters, equivalent to 60,000 barrels of oil per day. For the rest of the year, as you know we have a target of 1.95 million barrels of oil produced in Brazil, with a range of plus or minus 2.5%. We expect to meet the bottom range of these targets, as stagnants in the entire supply chain is causing delays in some of our day-to-day activities. So when the unexpected occurs which inevitably happens, solutions can be reached from the delay because of the lack of spare capacity in the industry. These delays in turn can reduce our average production for the year relative to our projected goal.

Let's go to slide four please, and look at the new drilling rigs. Our average production is also temporarily hampered by an insufficient number of drilling rigs to do all the exploration, operation and development and maintenance we would like. Fortunately our fleet will be increasing substantially in the near future. In 2009 and 2010, we will be adding 16 deep water drilling rigs to our existing inventory. Many of these rigs we ordered as far back as 2005, anticipating our increasing demand. You can also see in the table that we are contracting 12 additional new rigs that are scheduled for delivery in 2012. And we are planning to order an additional 28 rigs to be built in Brazil, with delivery between 2013 and 2017.

We are now in process of developing the building terms for these new builds. In addition to the drilling rigs we are also expanding our fleets of leased supply vessels to 146 to meet our growing needs. Let's see the slide five please. These are good moments to briefly discuss some of the processes that we are employing to increase the supply of equipment to develop our reserves. We have many challenges if we are to meet our targets, including equipments, human resources and cost inflation. We are addressing these challenges using a number of ways, such as long-term contracts, spend utilization of equipment and training program for those Petrobras employees in the supply chain.

We also recognized the need of increase in capacity to manufacture equipment for the offshore oil industry. Since the field has become one of the primary sources of demand for deep water equipment and services we are encouraging all our partners in the supply chain to add needed capacity in Brazil.

We strongly believe that there are advantages to doing so, ranging from reduced risk and efficiency to social and corporate responsibility as we help to create an industrial base that contributes to the wellbeing of the Brazilian society.

We believe we can accomplish builds in our aim that it is competitive with respect to the quality, timing and pricing. It is worth noting that national content has always been a criterion for the awarding of new upstream exploration blocks in Brazil.
In the most recent round, builders agreed to Brazilian content between 6 and 7% of their development costs. Slide six, please.

With the completion of Guara and Jupiter, wells , we will have completed at the time the minimal exploratory program of the exploration range for all the COGS reoperating samples without . There will not be any additional exploration while drilling built in the related to the program, with the exception of wells BM-S-22, operated by Exxon.

For the remainder of the year and before starting the appraisal content, we will continue evaluation the drilling results obtained thus far, and we will reenter our job RJS-646 in Tupi in preparation for the extended test scheduled for the first quarter of next year.

For complete in the yarra, we will also obtain additional high-resolution seismic data. While we have completed the exploration phase of the Santo platform, we continue to explore the Santos Basin. We are currently leading RJS-655 Taqualeen, block BM-S-45. And we will build Santa Catalina 13 and 14 grows to where we announced a find of light oil in June.

When the well being drilled in Jupiter is completed, the grid will move to check da moinya in the eastern margin to drill for the first time in a promising new frontier. We continue to manage the most important information we will get over the next 12 to 18 months will be the results of this extended tests at Tupi. These will give us a much better sense of the productivity of the pre-salt carbonate reservoir.

I should also mention that at the last executive board meeting, the unload project for Tupi was approved and we can now begin executing the contract that will lead to the production in December 2010. It is worth nothing that when BSS 102A in the pre-salt in the Espirito de Santos is completed and connected to the P-34 platform and we will begin producing shortly. This well, despite being more than 600 kilometers from the Santos pre-salt, is expected to provide valuable information due to the reliability of carbonate reservoir and the quality of volume.

Slide seven, please. Downstream. We will see later in the presentation that the prime sediment earnings were especially affected by the increase within the international price of oil and oil products. Operating therefore mostly however, was quite positive Brazilian refineries increased by 3% as a result of lower programmed maintenance, greater reliability and a higher charge of imported light oil.

To contend with too much light oil, and minimize our output of pure oil. As a result of this action, capacity utilization rose from 90 to 93%, although the percentage of the matched crude decreased to 77%. It is also worth nothing that in June, rah duke en refinery upgrade was completed. And we will start seeing the benefit of that upgrade beginning in the third quarter. When full operational, the coker will reduce our output of fuel oil by 22,000 barrels per day by increasing the output of coke, representing substantial margin improvement. Next year, we will have a similar coker being completed at Pet tree back.

As you can see sales volume of oil products increased by 3%. Most of the increase is concentrated in diesel, which grew by 8% in the first half of the year as compared to a year earlier. In contrast, sales declined by 1% during the first half of the year. I expect on our sales offset the growth of the .

Slide eight. Gas & power operational performance. Our operations of our Gas & Energy segment also continues to improve. As we will see, when we discussed results the segment results. Our Gas & Energy segment required a percent of operating and net income in this quarter. It is the result of a number of factors. Among them, higher volume of gas available for sale, higher margin from renegotiated sales contract to the distributors, completion of additional infrastructure to clear the gas, .

Some of these improvements are reflected in the slide 8, where as you can see gas-fired thermoelectric power is growing share of the electricity needs in Brazil. Giving Brazil's growth prospect and the higher cost of yield then less power. We don't see the need for gas-fired thermoelectric power diminishing. So, as we continue to add natural gas supply to regular fixed phase of LNG, the mass gas production and the completion of our natural gas infrastructure, we believe the segment we will continue to improve. Let's see the lifting costs in slide nine please.

During the quarter, the lifting costs slows by just over the $1 per barrel while rents increased by $24 during the same period. We just tried to minimize lifting cost, but it is more than half of such cost in material and third party services. Some correlation to the price of oil is inevitable. Given this cost environment, we are evaluating all of our standard operation prices to see how we can reduce costs. It also worth noting that lifting cost expressed in dollars are adversely affected by the real's trends. As evidenced, increases in lifting cost in reais has been much more constrained.
High oil price had also lapsed to a significant increase in our production factors. I gave the introduction P-52 and P-54 is subject to the highest bracket of the special tax.

Slide 10, please. Average realization price of oil products. Each quarter we disclose the price of the baskets of Brazilian products priced at United States Gulf Coast levels. Net adjusted for quality and transportation, we then track these against our actual sales in Brazil.

As you can see even though we increased price for diesel by 15% and gasoline by 10% at , it was not enough to offset the continued rise in international price. You will see also that for the first time both price were above the basket of U.S. products price, demonstrating the extent of reach of refining margin worldwide are being compared. The recent decline of Brent, which should substantially improve our balanced stream earnings in the third quarter.

Net income. Slide 11 please. Turning now to the financial results, higher price for our crude oil end product as well as volume builds the increase in the net income. Operating expenses were lower primarily as a result of reduced exploration expenses and had a chance of penalties from contract. Higher net financial expense were caused by a 9% strengthening of the real against dollar during the quarter.

The improvement of non-operating results were also caused by recognizing a gain of R$409 million from contributing the acquired Petrochemical assets the quarter. Income tax expense was higher not only because of higher operating costs but also because the absence of the interest on our own capital, during the quarter.

Let's see E&P in slide 12; income from our Brazilian E&P segment increased by 22% primarily as a result of higher price for crude oil sales. As mentioned earlier cost did increase but not to the same degree, as the increase in price. Most of the increase in cost is attributable to higher production taxes caused by higher prices.

Slide 13 downstream please; our downstream segment was adversely affected by price movement during the period. As discussed earlier we did pass two sizable price increases in May, however the cost of crude oil and products increased by an even greater margin causing a loss for this segment. This cost pressure were experienced by the refining industry worldwide as we showed in the performance of prices.

These costs would have been greater except for our accounting practice of average inventory purchase over time. When averaging costs in a rising price environment, costs , while in a declining price environment they will be higher. For the company as a whole, unit sales has had a positive pre tax income on our earnings of our first R$1 billion.

International operating income, slide 14. Our international segments results were improved by a more favorable price environment in markets where it operates, primarily Argentina. Lower exploratory costs and the absence of contingencies, related to Columbia royalties in the quarter contributed to higher net income quarter-over-quarter. With the first oil from Albany in before Nigeria to be followed by Abko, our international segment production is set to increase.

Gas & Power operating income slide 15. As mentioned earlier, our Gas & Energy segment are experiencing positive turnaround. Higher gas price from new contracts signed with distribution companies, higher volume of the net gas available for 70% gross, to 29 million liters per day. I in higher electrical generation as a result of more gas available, and the lower fine with relates to contractual supply of gas. All contributed to positive results for the quarter.

Slide 16, cash flow page. During the quarter, we generated a positive cash flow after CapEx of R$19 million. During the periods, EBITDA increased by 31% in relation to the first quarter of 2008. The paying out of dividends combined with modest increases in the net financing result in a small decline of cash balance of R$514 million.

Finally, the capital structure. Slide 17. Since most of our debt is given on the American dollar, the reevaluation of the real reduces our debt when expressed in reais. As a result, and combined with our gain earnings for the periods, our net debt to net total capital declined to 19% at the end of the period. This is well below the guidance of 25%, allowing for additional debt capacity if needed.
Thank you. At this time, I would be happy to answer any question you may have.
Thank you. . Thank you. Our first question is coming from Frank McGann of Merrill Lynch.

Yes. Good afternoon. Just three questions actually if I could. One is on lifting costs. How sustainable, or do you expect the pressure that you saw in this quarter for pure lifting costs, excluding taxes, to stay or do you think for because of higher volumes, those might come down?

Secondly, in terms of gas and energy, do you expect that this segment will now remain profitable as we go forward given the higher prices that you are receiving and the greater volumes that you are able to generate? And, maybe if you could go onto a little bit of detail on the cash price, how it's determined under the new distribution contracts?

And then last, just in terms of gas production and you mentioned the field that will be starting up later this year, I'm looking towards 2009, could you give us update on what the status of the Mistle Moffi is?

Okay, Frank. I am going to ask the help of Molinari to answer the first question about lifting costs and the gas production. And then to our friend from gas and energy to tell about the sustainability of the results.

Hi, Frank, regarding the lifting cost in reais, we have been continued to operate a percent in the last quarter compared to the first quarter of this year. On the, mainly due to materials purchased, personnel, little bit of personnel and sharpening of platforms. And also maintenance costs. And we expect the lifting cost to stabilize or go slightly down day-to-day increase in the production of P-52 and P-54 throughout the end of this year. The lifting cost in dollar was very much influenced by the exchange rate. So that is the lifting cost. I think it is sustainable for this year and to the end of this year this will be , but the lifting cost at this level or lower. These are the increase of production.
About the gas production?

Yeah, the gas production, we are increasing. We have to start production this year and the end of the year . Then leading toward the indicators the day of capacity. And the delivery to the market in the first nuclear region, the thin gas. We are reaching the target to deliver 40 million cubic meters a day in the first listed region to the market.
And the Sul well, how is that looking for the next year?
The Sul well, yeah, next year; sure, next year.
And the values that you are anticipating next year coming from that?
Yeah, it is the platform is being completed by the – . And things are going to deliver the project next year. Okay?

About the gas & power units, this will quarter-after-quarter, and we're still struggling and as these improving. And it depends basically on the energy markets. And the price that we paid for our gas, so that's the great viability of our . We can, what we can say is that we are, the admission that the liability of loss in the segment.
Okay. So, as long as your generation stays at reasonably strong levels, the level of profitability will be enhanced here?
The generation enterprise that we receive for that generation. And it depends also by the price that we pay for , you know.
Okay, thank you.
Just like to ask people when they ask questions if they could limit themselves to two question at a time, please. Thanks.
Thank you. Our next question comes from Arjun Murti of Goldman Sachs.

Thank you. Just a kind of a clarification and follow-up on some of the pre-salt commentary; just wanted to confirm that as far as the core piece of cluster goes, your comments were that we are going – you're going continue to participate in the Jupiter well and the Epson BMS-22. But besides that, you're primarily just going to be studying the results of the ten wells drilled to date, and preparing to extend the well test.

If I did hear that correct, if you can make any comments on that how much of that decision is driven by some of the contract uncertainty. Just a moment please.

We are just finishing the first phase or the minimal exploration program for the consult cluster. It does not mean that this is due to any change in the contract. This is just to comply with the terms of the contract we have in force. There is no change, there is not any established in this area. There has been discussion going on about the regulation of the government of Brazil create that can choose. It did not – is not part of Petrobras as the government being re-stepped. So there is no change at all.

So just to confirm, with these last few wells, you will have finished that first phase of exploration to test all the block. And then you're going to study the results. The extended wells tests, both the one that start that next year and I guess more importantly 2010 to Q3. You will want to see the results from the extended wells tests before contemplating full field development of Q3, but – is that all correct, what I just said?

Molinari, can you say something as far as I understand, yeah, it is going to be very important. The information I want to collect on the extended well test is going to be keen for our development of the field. But Molinari, can you add something?

Yeah, that's correct. What we want to see there that will behave or behavioral walk, especially on the pile of that we have water interaction, gas interaction. So we want to see how the regulator forms with those. And that will allow us to be right again, and importantly the development of them.

And I guess hopefully over the time period, by which you are studying result hopefully at some point within that timeframe, we will have better clarity on sort of how the country is thinking about pre-salt contract terms. I think is that fair statement?
On the new contracts will have been . I didn't quite catch what you said.

I mean the country is obviously going through an evaluation of how it wants to consider developing the pre-salt trend. That always take some time anywhere in the world and it will take some time Brazil. But you have a lot of studying to do whether it's of the extended well test or just the other information you've got from the wells. I presume you're going to want to – while you are studying these results somewhere within that timeframe, we ought to get some better certainty on how the country will go about developing these field and the timeframe hopefully overlap, plus at some point by the early next part of next decade, that will be then the timeframe by which you would be thinking about full field development of whether it's Tupi or the overall pre-salt cluster area.

I don't know if you can. I think what we've been trying to say is that we are following a process that begins with exploration, goes to appraisal. Within that appraisal, you have the extended well test, the pilot. And that that plan and process, it has nothing to do or is completely unrelated if you will or not affected by this other discussion that is there is going on. It's just – this is – what we are trying to do is explain what is the process now and is to get a process, that is not – it doesn't need to or in no way is thinking about this other issue.

That's very helpful. That was basically the question whether any of the uncertainty or rhetoric was at all causing you to delay how you are thinking about. But it sounds like it is two separate tracks, you are going to study the well tests, go about your business and whatever happen with everything else will happen in time.
This is – I think what we are trying to explain is how we think and what we are doing can most efficiently develop this whole new reserve and the blocks that are under concession.

Yeah it's very important to state that our program and our activity is not – has not changed a drop from what we were doing because of this discussion. We are following our route, we are doing what we had planned, we did not change in any sense what we were doing to collect all the information we need them to follow ahead with the development of the new findings.
Yes sir, thank you that answers my question, thank you very much.
Thank you.

And today we don't have any topsoil test in Jupiter, just completing the well and until beginning of September, when we are going to send the agreement in that will completed to the Cachalote Basin. That's our plan.

Right. One last question if I may, coming back to the comment about lifting costs. Every press release that we read about the lifting costs, the explanation is always the same, the raw materials, the personnel, . These are factors that affect basically lifting cost. I would like to understand how much more are you happy to explain the drilling or for lifting is too big to offset the decline of the acceleration of the decline of the fuels of the most predictive fuel at the moment. That price will be fairly to contrast, okay? And all the activity on the exchange rate regarding the decline rate, our decline rate is 10%, 10% per year. And so, that leaves .

Yes we have a project to improve the forms of the natural fuels. We view each peak as a goal and now we are reaching a second peak of production. So there are several things we are doing to improve the recovery factor of the fuels, we are injecting water, gas, some polyamides and so we are very, very much success in these techniques, especially on shore.

Yes well, DMC-14 is not, it is hard to say, unaccomplishable, but DMC-14 will be the next well drilled by . What's the other one?

Santa Catarina is BM-S-12.
13 and 14, is it south or north?

This is in shallow water and I don't think it's pre-salt there. It's shallow water, below 1,000 meters water there. Shall be about the same time of targets we drilled in the north discovery at the – It is also off BM-S-40. BM-S-40, recently they discovered there and I believe BM-S-12, it is south of BM-S-40, in shallow waters.
